hints.content:
An $\blueE{\text{even}}$ number is a number that can be split into $2$ equal groups.

We find $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers by making sure every object in the group has a pair.

![2 rows of cookies. Row 1 has 3 cookies. Row 2 has 3 cookies. A vertical dotted line divides the cookies into 3 columns so there are 3 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/9d50cd961bb1ee962eb60cc708a5e737e9d4486c)

Examples of $\blueE{\text{even}}$ numbers are $\blueE2, \blueE4,\blueE6, \blueE8, \blueE{10},  . .  .$

An $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ number **cannot** be split into $2$ equal groups. 

We find $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers by trying to pair objects and finding there is **not** always a pair.

![2 columns of cookies. Column 1 has 3 cookies. Column 2 has 2 cookies. A horizontal dotted line divides the cookies into 3 rows so there are 2 pairs and 1 extra cookie.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/10c3af09ebfcd0c6d05b4edd219f33894cc4d8b9)

Examples of $\maroonD{\text{odd}}$ numbers are $\maroonD1, \maroonD3, \maroonD5, \maroonD7, \maroonD9, . . . $

In this image, there are $\blueE4$ acorns.

![2 columns of acorns. Column 1 has 2 acorns. Column 2 has 2 acorns. A vertical dotted line divides the acorns into 2 columns so there are 2 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6002ccb37b7a31edc664db844c9ed13a0ff6770e)

Each acorn has a pair, so there are an even number of acorns.

In this image, there are $\blueE8$ acorns.

![4 rows of acorns. Each row has 2 acorns. A horizontal dotted line divides the acorns into 4 rows so there are 4 pairs.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/33dfa54fe702ab1832880424e0cdd8624ccc3c19)

Each acorn has a pair, so there are an even number of acorns.

In this image, there are $\maroonD7$ acorns.

![2 rows of acorns. Row 1 has 3 acorns. Row 2 has 4 acorns. A vertical dotted line divides the acorns into 4 columns so there are 3 pairs with 1 extra acorn.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/f65338279a4ec92200b4348060cc5c9aa32d70ee)

Each acorn does **not** have a pair, so there are an odd number of acorns.

This image shows an odd number of acorns:

![2 rows of acorns. Row 1 has 3 acorns. Row 2 has 4 acorns.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3adbd98f8f26ab8d1bee1bd310e33186c18df22f)

question.content:
**Which image shows an odd number of acorns?**

[[â˜ƒ radio 1]]

choices.content: ![2 rows of acorns. Row 1 has 3 acorns. Row 2 has 4 acorns.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/3adbd98f8f26ab8d1bee1bd310e33186c18df22f)
![2 rows of acorns. Row 1 has 2 acorns. Row 2 has 2 acorns.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/5fd1844c5b2c4d551ce18f42ff564dccc475732a)
![2 columns of acorns. Column 1 has 4 acorns. Column 2 has 4 acorns.](web+graphie://cdn.kastatic.org/ka-perseus-graphie/6c0fb9ebf381a38dd958a1dde2e35c406677ee06)
